questions.feedback_incorrect: Use saturation condition: |Vout| = |A(v₊ - v₋)| ≥ VCC. Minimum difference = VCC/A = 15V/10⁵ = 150μV.

questions.title: Negative Feedback Primary Function
questions.question_text: What is the primary engineering function of negative feedback in op-amp circuits?
questions.correct_answer: Create self-correcting system for stability and predictability
choices: Cause output saturation at supply rails
Create self-correcting system for stability and predictability
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Negative feedback creates self-regulation: deviations from desired operation are automatically corrected, ensuring stability and predictable behavior.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Negative feedback provides automatic error correction, making circuits stable and their behavior predictable and controllable.

questions.title: Negative Feedback Effect on Input Voltage Difference
questions.question_text: How does negative feedback affect the voltage difference (v₊ - v₋) between op-amp input terminals?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Negative feedback creates a control loop that actively works to minimize (v₊ - v₋) → 0, forming the basis of the Virtual Short Rule.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Negative feedback control action continuously works to reduce the input voltage difference toward zero.

questions.title: Negative Feedback Connection Point
questions.question_text: In op-amp circuits with negative feedback, to which input terminal is the output signal typically connected?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Negative feedback typically connects output to the inverting input (-) through a feedback network, creating the corrective action.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Negative feedback connects the output to the inverting input (-), either directly or through a feedback network.

questions.title: Circuit Gain Determination with Feedback
questions.question_text: When negative feedback is applied to an op-amp, what primarily determines the overall circuit gain and behavior?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! With negative feedback, the external components (typically resistors) in the feedback network determine circuit gain, not the op-amp's internal characteristics.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Negative feedback makes circuit behavior dependent on external feedback components rather than internal op-amp parameters.

questions.title: Open-Loop Operation Consequences
questions.question_text: Without negative feedback, an op-amp's high gain (10⁵-10⁶) means even tiny input differences will most likely cause:
questions.correct_answer: Output to saturate at voltage limits
choices: Output to saturate at voltage limits
Precise scaled output proportional to input
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! High open-loop gain amplifies tiny differences to large values: A×(small difference) = large output, typically exceeding supply limits (saturation).
questions.feedback_incorrect: Open-loop operation with high gain typically results in saturation because A×(v₊ - v₋) quickly exceeds ±VCC for any finite input difference.

questions.title: Negative Feedback Benefits Analysis
questions.question_text: Which is NOT a benefit of negative feedback in linear op-amp applications?
choices: Allows wider input signal range processing
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Signal inversion depends on circuit configuration (inverting vs. non-inverting), not feedback type. Negative feedback can be used in both inverting and non-inverting configurations.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Output signal polarity depends on circuit topology (inverting vs. non-inverting), not on the presence of negative feedback.

questions.title: Mechanical Stability Analogy
questions.question_text: The ball-in-valley mechanical analogy for negative feedback illustrates which system characteristic?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! The ball-in-valley analogy shows stable equilibrium: any displacement creates restoring forces that return the system to its stable position.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Ball-in-valley demonstrates stable equilibrium where perturbations create restoring forces, analogous to negative feedback error correction.

questions.title: Negative Feedback Definition
questions.question_text: Which statement best defines negative feedback in electronic systems?
choices: Configuration always results in signal inversion
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Negative feedback means the output signal opposes (counteracts) changes at the input, creating self-correcting behavior.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Negative feedback creates opposition to input changes, forming the basis for stable, self-regulating systems.

questions.title: Feedback Signal Input Terminal
questions.question_text: In standard negative feedback op-amp circuits, which input terminal typically receives the feedback signal?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Standard negative feedback connects the output to the inverting input (-) through the feedback network.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Negative feedback typically uses the inverting input (-) to receive the feedback signal from the output.

questions.title: Gain-Bandwidth Trade-off
questions.question_text: What happens to an op-amp's effective bandwidth when negative feedback reduces the circuit gain?
questions.correct_answer: Bandwidth increases proportionally to gain reduction
choices: Bandwidth decreases proportionally to gain reduction
Bandwidth increases proportionally to gain reduction
Bandwidth becomes zero for DC only
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Gain-bandwidth product is constant: GBW = A×BW = constant. When feedback reduces gain, bandwidth increases proportionally (GBW trade-off).
questions.feedback_incorrect: Due to gain-bandwidth product conservation, reducing gain through negative feedback proportionally increases the usable bandwidth.
